title: How will this lab help me?

list.problem: This lab will teach you how to use the Facebook login, Google Maps API, and camera through getUserMedia.
list.fix: The core lesson here is that there are third party APIs that we can utilize and avoid doing work that's already been done. You'll also get more practice using callbacks as the main form of communication between client and server. Even if you're not using any of these features in your assignments, hopefully this will get you started on using creating richer web applications.

list.problem: This isn't the only form callbacks take, or are used, but is an example! We'll see various forms of callbacks in the rest of the lab.

comment: Include facebook partials + add login button
title: Include the partials
facebook.js

list.fix: If you look in your index.handlebars, we put in the segment onlogin="checkLoginState();". This means after Facebook is done accepting your login API request, it will call the callback checkLoginState for you. See how varied callbacks can be used!

list.problem: How do I get the name from facebook to replace Michael Bernstein?
list.fix: Remember that the response data from facebook is stored in the response variable in changeUser. What's in response? Try printing it out onto the console!

list.problem: How do I get the image from facebook to use in my img?
list.fix: This is going to be similar to how we did it for name. Try peeking into what's inside response by logging it on the console. Try and see if you can get the URL to your facebook image to print onto the console.

list.problem: How do I replace just the src attribute of img?
list.fix: You can change a single attribute of an element with the jQuery call $.attr('src', );. Read more about it in the jQuery docs!

title: googleMaps.js

list.fix: If you look in your googleMaps.handlebars, we put in the segment &callback=initMap. This means after Google Maps is done accepting your API request, it will call the callback initMap for you. Another example of the varied usage of callbacks!

list.problem: What exactly are we implementing here?
list.fix: The video tag will show the video feed from our webcam. The canvas will show the image once we've taken the shot. Finally, the button will actually take the image!

list.problem: Woah woah slow down. How does all this work?
list.fix: Well it's slightly outside of the scope of this class, but you can read the capture function to understand how the video, canvas, and button are hooked together. The successCallback hooks up the video element to show the stream, and button's click to an event that draws the current image in video to the canvas. You can also see Dev.Opera - Media Capture in Mobile Browsers for a more detailed explanation.
